revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Kerri Kenney-Silver | image = NewImage500.jpg | imagesize = 250 | caption = Kenney on the set of ''Suburban Shootout'' in September 2008 | birth_name = Kerri Kenney | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1970|1|20}} | birth_place = [[Westport, Connecticut|Westport]], [[Connecticut]], U.S. | occupation = Actress, comedian, writer, musician | children = 1 | years_active = 1992–present | spouse = {{marriage|Steven V. Silver|2004}} }} '''Kerri Kenney-Silver''' (born January 20, 1970) is an American actress, comedian, writer, and musician. She is best known for starring as [[Trudy Wiegel]] on [[Comedy Central]]'s mockumentary series ''[[Reno 911!]]'' and previously for her sketch comedy work on [[MTV]]'s ''[[The State (1993 TV series)|The State]]'', where she was the show's lone female cast member. She has also appeared with recurring roles on sitcoms such as ''[[Superstore (TV series)|Superstore]]'', ''[[2 Broke Girls]]'', ''[[Love (TV series)|Love]]'', and ''[[The Ellen Show]]''. In the mid-late 1990's, Kenney fronted the all-female rock band [[Cake Like]]. ==Early life== Kenney-Silver was born '''Kerri Kenney''' in [[Westport, Connecticut]], the daughter of Sharon (McGaughey) and [[Larry Kenney]], an actor who is known for his classic [[voice over]] work.{{cite web|url=http://www.filmreference.com/film/88/Kerri-Kenney.html |title=Kerri Kenney Biography (1970–) |publisher=Filmreference.com |date=1970-01-20 |accessdate=2012-02-19}} She has a sister, Ashley, and a brother, Tanner. ==Career== During the early 1990s, Kenney-Silver was the lead singer and bass guitarist of the [[indie rock]] band [[Cake Like]]. Kenney-Silver attended [[NYU]] where she joined the sketch comedy group ''The New Group''{{cite book|last=Stulce|first=Corey|title=The Union of The State|pages=56–57|year=2016|ISBN=978-0997400519}}{{cite web|title=15 Things You Might Not Know About 'The State'|url=http://mentalfloss.com/article/57562/15-things-you-might-not-know-about-state|publisher=[[Mental Floss]]|date=July 10, 2014 |accessdate=August 30, 2016}} which ultimately became ''The State''.{{cite web|title=The State's David Wain, Thomas Lennon and Kerri Kenney-Silver|url=http://www.avclub.com/article/the-states-david-wain-thomas-lennon-and-kerri-kenn-23385|publisher=[[The A.V. Club]]|date=February 4, 2009|accessdate=August 30, 2016}} The group was picked up for a self-titled sketch comedy show on MTV, ''[[The State (1993 TV series)|The State]]'', which aired between 1993 and 1995. After the show's completion, Kenney-Silver continued working with her fellow troupe members on other projects. In 1996, she co-wrote and starred in ''[[Viva Variety]]'', a parody of variety shows that aired on [[Comedy Central]] for two seasons.{{cite web|url=http://splitsider.com/2014/09/revisiting-the-surreal-world-of-viva-variety/|title=Revisiting the Surreal World of ‘Viva Variety’|publisher=SplitSider|date=September 26, 2014|accessdate=August 30, 2016}} [[File:Orpheus RENO 911 (cropped).jpg|thumb|left|Kenney-Silver in character with ''Reno 911!'' co-star Thomas Lennon at Mardi Gras, 2009]] In 2000, Kenney-Silver voiced the character of "Gravitina" in the children's cartoon ''[[Buzz Lightyear of Star Command]]''. She has since done a number of voices on the [[Nickelodeon (TV channel)|Nickelodeon]] series ''[[Invader Zim]]''. Additionally, she was cast as a regular on ''[[The Ellen Show]]'', which aired until 2001. She later found success with ''[[Reno 911!]]'', a series on [[Comedy Central]] that parodied police reality shows like ''[[Cops (TV series)|COPS]]'', which also featured former members of the State, [[Thomas Lennon (actor)|Thomas Lennon]], [[Ben Garant]], and [[Joe Lo Truglio]]. The show was cancelled in 2009 after six seasons. Kenney-Silver also appeared on the TV series ''[[Still Standing (TV series)|Still Standing]]''. In July 2008, Kenney-Silver made her debut as "Dame Delilah", the title character in the [[web series]] ''Dame Delilah's Fantasy Ranch & Gift Shoppe''. On the site, various comedians give video testimony as characters working at or otherwise visiting the fictional Cat House. Kenney-Silver created the series and it was produced by her husband, Steve Silver, and Jared Mazzaschi.{{cite web|url=http://www.damedelilah.com |title=Dame Delilah's Fantasy Ranch & Gift Shoppe |publisher=Damedelilah.com |date= |accessdate=2012-01-20}} Kenney-Silver was among the cast of ''Suburban Shootout'', a pilot episode directed and executive produced by [[Barry Sonnenfeld]] for [[HBO]]. The pilot filmed in [[The Hamptons]], [[Long Island]], in September 2008. HBO has not announced if it will pick up the pilot for a season. The pilot is based on the [[British comedy]] [[Suburban Shootout|of the same name]].{{cite web|url=http://www.27east.com/story_detail.cfm?id=170793 |title=Hamptons familiar location for director |publisher=27east |date= |accessdate=2012-01-20}} Kenney-Silver has appeared in films such as ''[[All About Steve]]'', ''[[Reno 911!: Miami]]'', ''[[National Lampoon's Pledge This!]]'', ''[[Balls of Fury]]'', ''[[The Ten]]'', ''[[Role Models]]'', and ''[[Wanderlust (2012 film)|Wanderlust]]''. In December 2011 it was announced that Kenney-Silver and actress [[Jamie Denbo]] are developing a new series for [[Comedy Central]] called "Dame Delilah’s Rabbit Hole Ranch" based on a web series they previously created and starred in. In March 2012 it was announced Kenney-Silver had been cast a lead role in the [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] comedy pilot ''[[Counter Culture (TV series)|Counter Culture]]'' about three aging sisters (Kenney, [[Delta Burke]] and [[Margo Martindale]]) running their family diner together in [[West Texas]].{{cite web|author= Nellie Andreeva |url=http://www.deadline.com/2012/03/reno-911-alum-kerri-kenney-lands-a-lead-in-abc-comedy-pilot-counter-culture/|title=‘Reno 911′ Alum Kerri Kenney Lands A Lead In ABC Comedy Pilot ‘Counter Culture’|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|date=March 17, 2012|accessdate=April 7, 2012}} The pilot was not picked up for production by ABC. In 2015 she began voicing the character of Miriam in the ''[[Nickelodeon]]'' series ''[[Harvey Beaks]]''.{{cite web|url=http://chgreenblatt.tumblr.com/post/109468744982/could-you-at-least-tell-me-the-voice-actors-for|title=Nerd Armada|publisher=C.H. Greenblatt|date= January 29, 2015 |accessdate=January 29, 2015}} From 2016 to 2018, she recurred as Syd (the neighbor of [[Gillian Jacobs]]) in the [[Netflix]] comedy series ''[[Love (TV series)|Love]]''. She currently recurs on the [[NBC]] sitcom ''[[Superstore (TV series)|Superstore]]'', playing the role of Jerusha Sturgis, Glenn's wife, who was introduced in the third season. ==Personal life== Kenney-Silver is married to [[cinematographer]] Steven V. Silver. Their son, Kai, was born in 2005. ==Filmography== ===Film=== {| class="wikitable" width="100%" |- ! style="background:#ccc;" | Year ! style="background:#ccc;" | Title ! style="background:#ccc;" | Role ! style="background:#ccc;" | Notes |- | 1997 | ''Love God'' | Darla | |- | 1998 | ''Orange Quarters'' | First Funeral Mourner | |- | 1999 | ''[[Terror Firmer]]'' | Woman with Eyeball in Her Cleavage | |- | 2001 | ''[[Wet Hot American Summer]]'' | Paco's Wife | |- | 2003 | ''[[Kim Possible: The Secret Files]]'' | The Bebes (voice) | |- |2005 | ''[[Waiting...
